facts.fact: Otters hold hands while sleeping to keep from drifting apart.
Sea otters have the densest fur of any mammal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
There are 13 different species of otters found around the world.
Otters can stay underwater for up to 8 minutes.
Baby otters are called pups and are born blind.
Otters use tools like rocks to break open shellfish and crustaceans.
Sea otters eat up to 25% of their body weight every day.
River otters can swim at speeds of up to 7 miles per hour.
Otters are known for their playful behavior, often sliding down muddy banks.
Sea otters wrap themselves in kelp to anchor themselves while they sleep.
The giant otter, native to South America, can grow up to 6 feet in length.
Otters have a special pouch under their forearm to store favorite rocks.
The sea otter is one of the few marine mammals to use tools.
Otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater.
Sea otters play a key role in maintaining the balance of kelp ecosystems.
Otters live in a wide variety of aquatic environments, including rivers, lakes, and coastal areas.
Sea otters have no blubber, relying on their dense fur for warmth.
Otters are very social animals, often living in family groups called 'rafts.'
The Asian small-clawed otter is the smallest otter species, weighing less than 10 pounds.
River otters can hold their breath for up to 4 minutes underwater.
Otters have webbed feet, making them excellent swimmers.
Sea otters often use their chests as a table when cracking open shellfish.
In the wild, otters can live up to 16 years.
Otters groom themselves frequently to maintain the insulating quality of their fur.
A group of otters on land is called a 'romp,' while a group in the water is called a 'raft.'
Otters communicate with a variety of vocalizations, including whistles, growls, and screams.
Otters' whiskers help them detect vibrations in the water from prey.
Sea otters can dive to depths of 330 feet in search of food.
Otters are carnivores and primarily eat fish, crustaceans, and small invertebrates.
The North American river otter has one of the largest ranges of any otter species, stretching from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico.
Otters can have up to six pups in a litter, but two to three is more common.
Otters are territorial animals and often mark their territory with scent glands near their tails.
Sea otters can weigh between 30 and 100 pounds.
River otters are often seen playing games, like sliding down slopes or chasing each other.
Sea otters are found along the coasts of the northern and eastern Pacific Ocean.
The main predator of sea otters is the orca.
Otters have a very high metabolic rate to help them stay warm in cold water.
Giant otters are social animals and live in family groups of up to 20 individuals.
Otters have excellent hearing and smell, which helps them detect predators and locate food.
The Eurasian otter is the most widely distributed otter species, found across Europe, Asia, and parts of Africa.
Otters have been known to use tools like sticks and stones to help with feeding.
Sea otters can consume over 40 different species of marine life, including sea urchins and crabs.
Sea otters have retractable claws similar to those of a cat.
Otters have a strong bond with their young, and mothers are very protective.
River otters can travel up to 18 miles on land between bodies of water.
Sea otters help control the sea urchin population, which helps protect kelp forests.
Otters are considered a 'keystone species' due to their role in ecosystem stability.
Otters are highly adaptable and can live in a wide range of habitats, from rivers to coastal waters.
The smooth-coated otter is native to South and Southeast Asia and is the largest otter species in Asia.
Otters are known to mimic each other’s actions, particularly while hunting and playing.
Otters are often seen floating together in large groups called 'rafts,' which can consist of dozens of otters.
